column1:
commodity /kəˈmɒdəti/
Examples: Coffee is a common commodity in many countries.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Anything movable (a good) that is bought and sold.

snub /snʌb/
Examples: I hope the people we couldn't invite don't see it as a snub.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A deliberate affront or slight.
column2: A sudden checking of a cable or rope.

column1:
snub /snʌb/
Examples: He snubbed my offer of help.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To slight, ignore or behave coldly toward someone.

impetuous /imˈpɛtʃuəs/
Examples: He acted impetuously, rushing into the situation without considering the consequences.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Making arbitrary decisions, especially in an impulsive and forceful manner.
column2: Characterized by sudden violence or vehemence.

column1:
succumb /səˈkʌm/
Examples: Thai culture as in many other Asian cultures, is succumbing to the influence of westernization.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To yield to an overpowering force or overwhelming desire.
column2: To give up, or give in.

column1:
emanate /ˈɛm.ə.ˌneɪt/
Examples: Fragrance emanates from flowers.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To come from a source

flounder /ˈflaʊndɚ/
Examples: The fisherman caught a flounder during his morning fishing trip.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A European species of flatfish having dull brown colouring with reddish-brown blotches
column3: Any of various flatfish of the family Pleuronectidae or Bothidae.

column1:
eminent /ˈɛmɪnənt/
Examples: His eminent good sense has been a godsend to this project.,"Part of Speech: adjective

embroiled 
Examples: Avoid him. He will embroil you in his fights.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To draw into a situation

transfix 
Examples: The actor's performance transfixed the audience, leaving them in awe.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To render motionless, by arousing terror, amazement or awe.
column2: To pierce with a sharp pointed weapon.

column1:
visceral /ˈvɪsəɹəl/
Examples: Her visceral reaction to the news shook her whole being.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to the viscera—internal organs of the body.
column2: Having to do with the response of the body as opposed to the intellect, as in the distinction between feeling and thinking.

column1:
anthropologist /ˌæn.θɹoʊˈpɑl.ə.d͡ʒɪst/
Examples: The anthropologist analyzed the artifacts to understand ancient human settlements.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: One who is versed in anthropology.

niche /niːʃ/
Examples: The company identified a niche market for eco-friendly products.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A cavity, hollow, or recess, generally within the thickness of a wall, for a statue, bust, or other erect ornament. Hence, any similar position, literal or figurative.
column2: A function within an ecological system to which an organism is especially suited.

column1:
niche /niːʃ/
Examples: a niched vase,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To place in a niche.
column2: To specialize in a niche, or particular narrow section of the market.

column1:
culminate /ˈkʌlmɪneɪt/
Examples: The expedition culminated in a successful mission.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: Of a heavenly body, to be at the highest point, reach its greatest altitude.
column2: To reach the (physical) summit, highest point, peak etc.

column1:
culminate /ˈkʌlmɪneɪt/
Examples: The festival culminated in a celebration.,"Part of Speech: adjective

stifle /ˈstaɪfəl/
Examples: The horse's stifle was injured.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A hind knee of various mammals, especially horses.
column2: A bone disease of this region.

column1:
stifle /ˈstaɪfəl/
Examples: The army stifled the rebellion.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To interrupt or cut off.
column2: To repress, keep in or hold back.

column1:
chasten /ˈtʃeɪ.sən/
Examples: The coach chastened the player for their careless mistakes.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To punish (in order to bring about improvement in behavior, attitude, etc.)

province /ˈpɹɒvɪns/
Examples: The French province of Alsace is known for its historic architecture.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A region of the earth or of a continent
column3: An administrative subdivision of certain countries, including Canada and China.

column1:
rigor /ɹɪɡɚ/
Examples: The researcher demonstrated rigorous methodology in their experiments.,"Part of Speech: noun

rigor /ɹɪɡɚ/
Examples: The researcher demonstrated rigorous methodology in their experiments.,"Part of Speech: noun

kindled /ˈkɪndl̩d/
Examples: He kindled an enthusiasm for the project in his fellow workers.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To start (a fire) or light (a torch, a match, coals, etc.).
column2: To arouse or inspire (a passion, etc).

column1:
kindled /ˈkɪndl̩d/
Examples: She kindled the fire with a match.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: (of a rabbit or hare) To bring forth young

maneuver /məˈnuːvə/
Examples: Joint NATO maneuvers are as much an exercise in diplomacy as in tactics and logistics.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The planned movement of troops, vehicles etc.
column3: (later also) a large training field-exercise of fighting units.

column1:
maneuver /məˈnuːvə/
Examples: The pilot performed a precise maneuver to avoid the storm.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To move (something, or oneself) carefully, and often with difficulty, into a certain position.

complacency 
Examples: The team felt complacent after winning the championship.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A feeling of contented self-satisfaction, especially when unaware of upcoming trouble.

tact /tækt/
Examples: The manager demonstrated great tact in handling the employee's conflict.,"Part of Speech: noun

tact /tækt/
Examples: She tactfully addressed the issue without causing any embarrassment.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To use a tact (a kind of verbal operant

oar /ɔː/
Examples: He is a good oar.,"Part of Speech: noun

Definition: A type of lever used to propel a boat, having a flat blade at one end and a handle at the other, and pivoted in a rowlock atop the gunwale, whereby a rower seated in the boat and pulling the handle can pass the blade through the water by repeated strokes against the water's resistance, thus moving the boat .

oar /ɔː/
Examples: The sailor oared through the calm waters of the lake.,"Part of Speech: verb

column2: to travel with, or as if with, oars.

column1:
propel /pɹəˈpɛl/
Examples: The engine propelled the boat forward.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To provide an impetus for motion or physical action, to cause to move in a certain direction
column3: To provide an impetus for non-physical change, to make to arrive to a certain situation or result.

column1:
bohemian /boʊˈhimi.ən/
Examples: The bohemian artist painted vividly, embracing the chaos of life.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: An unconventional or nonconformist artist or writer.

bohemian /boʊˈhimi.ən/
Examples: The bohemian painter preferred to live in a remote cabin rather than join the corporate world.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Unconventional, especially in habit or dress.

bleak /bliːk/
Examples: A bleak and bare rock.,"Part of Speech: adjective

attest /əˈtɛst/
Examples: When will the appraiser attest the date of the painting?; You must attest your will in order for it to be valid.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To affirm to be correct, true, or genuine.
column2: To certify by signature or oath.

column1:
obscure /əbˈskjɔː(ɹ)/
Examples: The professor obscured the key points of the lecture by using obscure references.,"Part of Speech: verb

column6: to make less visible, intelligible, legible, glorious, beautiful, or illustrious.
column7: To hide, put out of sight etc.

column1:
obscure /əbˈskjɔː(ɹ)/
Examples: The ancient manuscript was obscure to most scholars.,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: Hidden, out of sight or inconspicuous.

column1:
frugal /ˈfɹuːɡəl/
Examples: He lives frugally, avoiding unnecessary expenses.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Avoiding unnecessary expenditure either of money or of anything else which is to be used or consumed

geodesic /ˌd͡ʒiːəˈdiːsɪk/
Examples: The geodesic between two points on a sphere is a great circle.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The shortest line between two points on a specific surface.
column2: (spherical geometry) A segment of a great circle.

column1:
geodesic /ˌd͡ʒiːəˈdiːsɪk/
Examples: The surveyor used geodesic techniques to measure the land accurately.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to geodesy.
column2: Of or relating to a geodesic dome.

column1:
deviate /ˈdiːvi.ət/
Examples: The deviation in the data caused confusion among the team.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A person with deviant behaviour
column3: A value equal to the difference between a measured variable factor and a fixed or algorithmic reference value.

column1:
deviate /ˈdiːvi.ət/
Examples: His exhibition of nude paintings deviated from the norm.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To go off course from
column4: To fall outside of, or part from, some norm

column1:
assail /əˈseɪl/
Examples: Muggers assailed them as they entered an alley.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To attack with harsh words or violent force (also figuratively).

diversions 
Examples: The kids enjoyed the various diversions offered at the carnival.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A tactic used to draw attention away from the real threat or action.
column3: an activity that distracts the mind.

column1:
men /mɛn/
Examples: The show is especially popular with middle-aged men.,"Part of Speech: noun

men /mɛn/
Examples: "Muster up the men in the barracks at 0600," the lieutenant said to his sergeant.,"Part of Speech: noun

column2: (collective) enlisted personnel (as opposed to commissioned officers).

column1:
deficiency /dɪˈfɪʃənsi/
Examples: Her diet was deficient in essential nutrients.,"Part of Speech: noun

column2: An insufficiency, especially of something essential to health.

column1:
guise /ˈɡaɪz/
Examples: He acted in a different guise to hide his real intentions.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Customary way of speaking or acting
column2: fashion, manner, practice (often used formerly in such phrases as ""at his own guise""
column3: that is, in his own fashion, to suit himself.)
column4: External appearance in manner or dress

column3: to go dressed up in a parade etc.

daemon /ˈdiː.mən/
Examples: The daemon was summoned to protect the kingdom.,"Part of Speech: noun

wed /ˈwɛd/
Examples: The priest wed the couple.; She wed her first love.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To perform the marriage ceremony for

bourgeoisie /ˌbʊə(ɹ)ʒwɑːˈziː/
Examples: The bourgeoisie dominated the economic landscape of 19th-century France.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A class of citizens who were wealthier members of the third estate.

notary 
Examples: The notary signed the documents confirming the marriage.,"Part of Speech: noun

Definition: A lawyer of noncontentious private civil law who drafts, takes, and records legal instruments for private parties, and provides legal advice, but does not appear in court on clients' behalf.
column2: (common law) A notary public, a legal practitioner who prepares, attests to, and certifies documents, witnesses affidavits, and administers oaths.

column1:
ethnicity /ɛθˈnɪsɪti/
Examples: The community's ethnic diversity contributes to its unique cultural identity.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The common characteristics of a group of people, especially regarding ancestry, culture, language or national experiences.

elitist 
Examples: The elitist philosopher rejected the idea of meritocracy, believing that true leadership came from inherited privilege.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: (usually derogatory) Someone who believes in or is perceived as believing in rule by an elite group.

elitist 
Examples: The elitist CEO favored only the most skilled employees, ignoring those from lower-tier backgrounds.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Of or relating to elitism.

contemporary /kənˈtɛm.p(ə).ɹi/
Examples: Cervantes was a contemporary of Shakespeare.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Someone or something living at the same time, or of roughly the same age as another.
column2: Something existing at the same time.

column1:
contemporary /kənˈtɛm.p(ə).ɹi/
Examples: The museum exhibition features contemporary art pieces.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: From the same time period, coexistent in time.

institution /ˌɪnstɪˈtjuːʃən/
Examples: The university is an important institution in the community.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A custom or practice of a society or community.
column2: An organization similarly long established and respected, particularly one involved with education, public service, or charity work.

column1:
lucrative 
Examples: That new job is lucrative.,"Part of Speech: adjective

patriarch /ˈpeɪtɹɪɑːk/
Examples: The patriarch of the family decided to retire.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The highest form of bishop, in the ancient world having authority over other bishops in the province but now generally as an honorary title
column2: in Roman Catholicism, considered a bishop second only to the Pope in rank.
column3: In Biblical contexts, a male leader of a family, tribe or ethnic group, especially one of the twelve sons of Jacob (considered to have created the twelve tribes of Israel) or (in plural) Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

column1:
foster /ˈfɒstə/; /ˈfɑstɚ/
Examples: Some fosters end up adopting.,"Part of Speech: noun

foster /ˈfɒstə/; /ˈfɑstɚ/
Examples: Our company fosters an appreciation for the arts.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To nurture or bring up offspring, or to provide similar parental care to an unrelated child.

erode /ɪˈɹoʊd/
Examples: to erode a person's trust,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To wear away by abrasion, corrosion or chemical reaction.
column2: To destroy gradually by an ongoing process.

column1:
palate /ˈpælət/
Examples: The restaurant's new menu was highly praised for its ability to please the diverse palate of its customers.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The roof of the mouth

palate /ˈpælət/
Examples: She palate the dessert to determine its taste.,"Part of Speech: verb

appear /əˈpiːɹ/
Examples: A great writer appeared at that time.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To come or be in sight

innate /ɪˈneɪt/
Examples: The painter innate the colors into the canvas.,"Part of Speech: verb

innate /ɪˈneɪt/
Examples: innate ideas,"Part of Speech: adjective

column2: existing or having existed since birth.
column3: Originating in, or derived from, the constitution of the intellect, as opposed to acquired from experience.

column1:
groom /ɡɹuːm/
Examples: The groom stood beside the bride as they exchanged vows.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A man who is about to marry.

equate /ɪˈkweɪt/
Examples: The equation of the line is y = mx + b.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A statement in assembly language that defines a symbol having a particular value.

equate /ɪˈkweɪt/
Examples: She equated the two ideas as equally important.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To consider equal or equivalent.

barnacle /ˈbɑːnəkl̩/; /ˈbɑɹnəkl̩/
Examples: The barnacle grew on the stone wall.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A marine crustacean of the subclass Cirripedia that attaches itself to submerged surfaces such as tidal rocks or the bottoms of ships.

barnacle /ˈbɑːnəkl̩/; /ˈbɑɹnəkl̩/
Examples: The ship's crew barnailed the life jacket to the hull.,"Part of Speech: verb
Definition: To connect with or attach.

drudgery /ˈdɹʌdʒəɹi/
Examples: The factory worker endured drudgery as part of their daily routine.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: Tedious, menial, and exhausting work.

uncanny /ʌnˈkæni/
Examples: The uncanny experience left a lasting impression.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: (Freud) Something that is simultaneously familiar and strange, typically leading to feelings of discomfort
column2: translation of Freud's usage of the German ""unheimlich"" (literally ""unsecret"").

column1:
uncanny /ʌnˈkæni/
Examples: He bore an uncanny resemblance to the dead sailor.,"Part of Speech: adjective
Definition: Strange, and mysteriously unsettling (as if supernatural)

grain /ɡɹeɪn/
Examples: We stored a thousand tons of grain for the winter.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: The harvested seeds of various grass food crops eg: wheat, corn, barley.
column2: Similar seeds from any food crop, e.g., buckwheat, amaranth, quinoa.

column1:
grain /ɡɹeɪn/
Examples: The baker grains the flour to make bread.,"Part of Speech: verb

subtle /ˈsʌt(ə)l/
Examples: The difference is subtle, but you can hear it if you listen carefully.,"Part of Speech: adjective

primate /ˈpɹaɪmeɪt/
Examples: Primates range from lemurs to gorillas.,"Part of Speech: noun
Definition: A mammal of the order Primates, including simians and prosimians.
